results.title: Land of invention
results.brief_description: Famous Scotsmen who have been responsible for many valuable contributions to the machine age include: Macadam, known for “macadamised” roads; Watt, who developed the steam engine; Murdoch, who developed gas-lighting; Masmyth, designer of the steam hammer; Graham Bell, inventor of the telephone; Telford, engineer responsible for the building of the Caledonian canal; and Simpson, who developed chloroform for use as an anaesthetic.

results.title: Land of hype and glory
results.creator_credit: Karen Lerner, Films Incorporated and Tom Priestly
results.brief_description: This film focuses on two markets - literary and cinema - to show how the public is manipulated by extravagant promotion. Many tools are used by publishers to help create best-sellers, and movie hype is big business.

results.title: Land of gold
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Peach’s gold”.
Using dramatised re-enactments as well as historical footage, Bill Peach investigates the economic crash of the 1890s and the exhaustion of the goldfields at Ballarat and Bendigo. He describes how the less well known but far more productive goldfields at Coolgardie and Kalgoorlie rescued Australia from the depths of depression and continued to contribute to the country’s economy up to the early 1980s.

results.title: Land of enlightenment
results.creator_credit: M. Bhavnani, Films Division, Government of India and Mohan Wadhwani
results.brief_description: This film follows the progress of a Chinese pilgrim through the blessed land of Bihar, “The Land of Englightenment”, which was once the centre of learning and worship for students of Central Asia, China, Burma and Ceylon; the land where Buddha was born. Every pillar, arch and relic from Sarnath, Sonapur and Patna, Nalanda and Vaishali, Pavapuri, and Bodh Gaya to Rajgir, speak of the message of Sakyamuni to the devout pilgrim.

results.title: Land of Cyprus
results.brief_description: Shows how timber-getting, grazing of goats, wind and water have all contributed to the problem of soil erosion in Cyprus. Explains how the British Government is tackling the problem; building dams, developing irrigation methods, stamping out malarial mosquitoes, teaching contour ploughing and terracing, planting new forests. The film mentions the difficulties of over-crowded towns and increasing population.

results.title: Land mines: a love story
results.brief_description: Land mines remain a danger in 82 countries around the world, and between 15,000 and 20,000 people become fresh victims of land mines every year. Afghanistan (one of the countries worst affected) is estimated to still have ten million unexploded landmines in the ground. Veteran Australian documentary filmmaker Dennis O’Rourke travelled to Afghanistan in 2001 to make this film about how land mines have affected the lives of ordinary Afghani people. In the chaos of war-ravaged Kabul, O’Rourke met Habiba, a Tajik woman who lost one of her legs to a land mine in 1992 at age 11. Habiba is married to Shah, a former Mujaheddin fighter, also disabled as a result of his war injuries. The result is a film that, while showing the destruction and suffering caused by war, also celebrates life, love and hope for the future. (Awards: Winner of the 2005 AFI Award for Best Documentary).

results.title: Land from the sky
results.brief_description: Records the use of aircraft as an aid to farming in the hill country in New Zealand. From the early days when pilots made hazardous trips in old air force planes - landing and taking off from any strip of paddock, aerial topdressing has today developed into a well organised industry restoring dangerously eroded hill country. Planes are now used extensively for other farm work such as spraying and rabbit poisoning.

results.title: Land divers of Melanesia
results.creator_credit: Phoenix Films, Robert Gardner and Karl Muller
results.brief_description: Documents the salient features of the intact culture of Melanesia, including agriculture, play and ritual of Bunlap on Pentecost Island in the New Hebrides. Shows the relationship between yam agriculture and ceremonies such as land diving.

results.title: Land behind the dikes: the Netherlands
results.creator_credit: John Ferno and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Makes the point that the Netherlands, with about one-half of the land area below sea level, is largely man-made. Illustrates draining, reclamation, farming, the use of canals for transport, and the richness of the polders.
